metadata.title: 5 Things To Know: June 16, 2025
metadata.description:
CNBC’s Becky Quick reports on the 5 things to know on June 16, 2025. For access to live and exclusive video from CNBC subscribe to CNBC PRO: https://cnb.cx/42d859g

» Subscribe to CNBC TV: https://cnb.cx/SubscribeCNBCtelevision
» Subscribe to CNBC: https://cnb.cx/SubscribeCNBC
» Watch CNBC on the go with CNBC+: https://www.cnbc.com/WatchCNBCPlus

transcript.full_text:
All right, five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. Israel's military says that it has achieved aerial superiority over Iran's capital, Tehran. It's the fourth day of fighting between the two countries since Israel launched attacks on Iran's nuclear infrastructure. US Ambassador to Israel, Mike Huckabee said that the US Embassy branch in Tel Aviv sustained minor damage from shockwaves from a nearby explosion, but no US personnel were injured.

President Trump has approved Nippon Steel's nearly $15 billion dollar bid for US Steel after 18 months of twists and turns. That deal includes $11 billion in new investments by the year 2028. It will boost Nippon's annual production capacity to 86 million metric tons of steel. That is up from 63 million tons. And shares of French fashion house, Kering are up sharply in European trading. That follows reports that the company has appointed Renault CEO Luca de Meo as its next CEO. Kering has not confirmed that report, but Renault said yesterday that de Meo was stepping down to take on challenges outside the automotive sector.

Taiwan's Commerce Ministry adding Chinese chip makers Huawei and SMIC to its export control list. That means Taiwanese companies will have to obtain permits before selling products to the Chinese companies. And a cyber attack on the Washington Post compromised the email accounts of several journalists, including those on the national security and economic policy teams. In an internal memo yesterday, the paper's executive editor notified staff about the intrusion into its email system. The paper believes a foreign government could be responsible for that attack.

analysis.summary:
The report highlights five significant global developments impacting markets. Firstly, in the Middle East, Israel's military has declared aerial superiority over Iran's capital, Tehran, marking the fourth consecutive day of conflict stemming from Israel's initial attacks on Iran's nuclear infrastructure. Concurrently, the US Embassy branch in Tel Aviv sustained minor damage from nearby explosion shockwaves, though no American personnel were harmed, as confirmed by US Ambassador to Israel, Mike Huckabee.

Economically, a major business deal sees President Trump's approval of Nippon Steel's roughly $15 billion acquisition of US Steel, a culmination of an 18-month negotiation. This deal includes a substantial $11 billion in new investments by Nippon Steel slated for completion by 2028, and is projected to significantly boost Nippon's annual steel production capacity from 63 million to 86 million metric tons. In the fashion sector, Kering's shares surged in Europe amid reports of Luca de Meo, current Renault CEO, being appointed as Kering's new CEO, although Kering has not verified this, Renault confirmed de Meo's departure to pursue opportunities outside the automotive industry.

In technology and cybersecurity news, Taiwan's Commerce Ministry has imposed stricter export controls by adding Chinese chipmakers Huawei and SMIC to its restricted list, necessitating permits for Taiwanese companies to sell products to them. Lastly, a cyber attack targeting the Washington Post compromised email accounts of several journalists, particularly those on the national security and economic policy teams. The paper's executive editor informed staff about the intrusion, and the Washington Post suspects a foreign government's involvement in the attack.

key_points.text: Israel's military claims aerial superiority over Iran's capital, Tehran.
This is the fourth day of fighting between Israel and Iran.
Israel initiated attacks on Iran's nuclear infrastructure.
US Ambassador to Israel, Mike Huckabee, reported minor damage to the US Embassy branch in Tel Aviv.
The damage to the embassy was caused by shockwaves from a nearby explosion.
No US personnel were injured in the Tel Aviv incident.
President Trump approved Nippon Steel's nearly $15 billion bid for US Steel.
The approval of the Nippon Steel-US Steel deal followed an 18-month process.
The deal includes $11 billion in new investments by Nippon Steel into US Steel by the year 2028.
The acquisition will boost Nippon Steel's annual production capacity from 63 million tons to 86 million metric tons.
Shares of French fashion house Kering are up sharply in European trading.
Reports suggest Kering has appointed Renault CEO Luca de Meo as its next CEO.
Kering has not confirmed the report regarding Luca de Meo's appointment.
Renault announced yesterday that Luca de Meo was stepping down from his CEO position.
De Meo's departure from Renault is to pursue challenges outside the automotive sector.
Taiwan's Commerce Ministry added Chinese chipmakers Huawei and SMIC to its export control list.
Taiwanese companies now require permits to sell products to Huawei and SMIC.
A cyber attack compromised email accounts of several Washington Post journalists.
Journalists on the national security and economic policy teams were affected by the cyber attack.
The Washington Post's executive editor informed staff about the email system intrusion via an internal memo yesterday.
The Washington Post suspects a foreign government is responsible for the cyber attack.
The news provides five key developments ahead of today's market opening.

US Embassy branch in Tel Aviv sustained minor damage from shockwaves from a nearby explosion.
President Trump approved Nippon Steel's bid for US Steel.

temporal_patterns.description: A progression of fighting between Israel and Iran, now in its fourth day since the initial attacks.
A long-term negotiation process spanning 18 months, culminating in a deal approval.
A future commitment for investments with a specific deadline.
